audio_caption: The clip starts with a male speaker talking about "one of the most popular and loved languages on this planet, according to Microsoft".  Then music begins, which appears to be electronic in style, playing loudly and rhythmically with an energetic tone. The speaker returns, uttering, "I'm ready", then names "Microsoft Java," before correcting it to, "C Sharp." The speaker continues describing C Sharp, "struggling to keep track whether C Sharp is cross-platform or not," and explaining it's always been cross-platform, noting "it's 2022, Microsoft is different now, object-oriented, and declarative, and functional."  He continues talking about dot net framework being more than C Sharp and creating your own language, adding, "but nothing beats C Sharp," and discusses "tweaks and changes and changes on top of changes."

The clip begins with a deep male voice stating, "That was decades ago," which is immediately followed by another male voice, with a slightly more enthusiastic tone, correcting "one decade ago." The second speaker continues, stating that "C# is different now," and goes on to say that "C# has always been cross platform" since 2016, and "always been open source" since 2014, questioning why one would let the community contribute to something "so perfect and evolving," with a more rhetorical tone. Finally, the speaker emphasizes "C#" followed by "Microsoft."

The audio clip starts with a male speaker enthusiastically discussing C Sharp as a suite of tools, naming "Visual Studio", "corporate", and ".net". He questions, in a pondering tone, how people write code without Visual Studio. He then mentions that "C Sharp and .Net are separable," and goes on to quickly list different variations of .Net, like ".net core", ".net framework", ".net micro framework", ".net compact framework" and others. The speaker sounds out of breath as he reaches ".Net Five". The recording ends with a sigh.

The audio clip opens with a male speaker musing on the C# programming language, contrasting it with other languages and mentioning features such as the "nullability operator." He lists several related technologies including "Skype," ".Net", and "common language runtime." The speaker emphasizes the popularity of C#, countering an objection about its popularity from a comment, perhaps from "2015." Finally, he signs off stating he will be in the studio. The speaker speaks in a calm, conversational tone.

The audio clip begins with a male speaker passionately promoting the benefits of C#, mentioning its "second mover advantage," a "great community of experts," and "expensive consultants." He then highlights ASP.NET's popularity as a web application framework, mentioning ASP.NET Core, before continuing to describe the popularity of C# as making one "marketable in the marketplace." He concludes with the statement, "it's not just marketing."

The audio clip begins with a male speaker enthusiastically emphasizing the financial benefits of learning C#, stating "Look at all the opportunities for C# devs out there". He continues, expressing the sentiment that C# should be learned for financial gain rather than pleasure, stating "You don't learn C# to have fun". He further elaborates on this, suggesting a cycle of using earnings from C# to then have fun learning more C# to earn even more. The male speaker then states "Let's uncover a great myth here" and clarifies that C# isn't only for game development.

The audio clip begins with a male speaker talking about Unity and being "not sponsored by" Microsoft, his tone is informative. A loud crashing sound interrupts the speech. The speaker resumes, noting that "the survey isn't biased by vendor lock-in" and discussing C# and VR. A cough follows. He mentions "HoloLens" and features of C#, such as "implicit types, anonymous functions." His voice is slightly elevated and energetic when talking about new features.

The clip begins with a man providing tech jargon, naming a series of programming language terms like "unary plus, link, C# mascot Andy, .net mascot, .net bot, malware mascot, .net botnet". He then shifts in tone, making a skeptical remark about the necessity of features, stating "they're not just adding random stuff no one asks for; I asked for it". A lighthearted complaint follows: "no one asked me. C++ is a waste of time." He emphasizes that C++ is "faster than anything that is not compiled, strongly typed." He continues with a mix of technical comparisons and opinion, discussing stability and security, mentioning "Java and C# are totally different things" and noting the differences in their virtual machines and frameworks. A dismissive tone returns with "no competitor has this." The man concludes with a product-oriented focus stating, "Let's talk about Azure. Azure pipeline"

The audio clip features one male speaker discussing similarities between Microsoft's C# and Java, mentioning "mutual stealing," "copying," and "inspiration," and explaining dynamic types. His tone is analytical and slightly critical. The speaker notes changes made in the switch statement.

The audio clip features a male speaker passionately discussing technical concepts with enthusiasm, referencing topics like "garbage collector" and "pointers," and frequently interjecting with rhetorical questions, such as "But why?" and "Why would anyone?" There's a brief interlude where he mentions "implicit using," "having a function," and "having a runtime." Then, the speaker apologizes, stating that the "boss was calling." The clip concludes with the speaker abruptly saying "Shh" before ending.

The clip begins with a synthesized tone, followed by a male speaker's voice discussing C# programming language features and aspects in a clear, informational tone. He uses various phrases like "innovation", "are you bored?", "default skeleton is not the same", and touches upon topics like "just in time", "anonymous functions", and its similarities with Java and JavaScript. Occasionally he voices concerns using a tone tinged with humor. The speech is clear and professional. A subtle hum of background ambiance exists in the clip. The speaker continues with more commentary on C#, adding suspense, before suddenly exclaiming about seeing a C developer, questioning their presence in a C# environment, highlighting the specialized nature of their environment. As he continues his talk, he expresses enthusiasm and humor.

The clip begins with a male speaker humorously comparing C# and .NET versions to being "on steroids," and then jokes about "fake teeth" and "too much syntax sugar." He introduces something to "buy you in", which he clarifies means to "convince, unbiased." There is a sound of something breaking, after which the speaker comments on the chair not being of "Microsoft quality," and reintroduces the idea of something to "buy you in." The clip concludes with a sound of breaking something, presumably the chair. The speaker's tone is jovial and lighthearted, shifting to a slightly annoyed tone when the chair breaks.

The clip starts with a male speaker stating that "hardly anybody will claim" Java or C# are "revolutionary programming languages" that have "changed the way we do things" with a fairly neutral tone. His tone turns more emphatic when he says, "Nobody ever. C# is the greatest." Next, the same speaker makes an aside, "Oh, we had that already." The speaker continues, saying "the LTS is three years," and explains that "people cannot explain to the clients that they have to modernize their software every three years," but declares confidently, "I can. I can." The speaker then uses an expression that sounds like "symbol soup." Another speaker interjects, stating, "Just chiming in to say that I really like the new nullability operator, and I really like to use it." Finally, the first speaker concludes with a light-hearted tone, "Well, that wasn't that hard. Couple of lies here and there, huh?"

The audio begins with a male speaker discussing Windows Forms and related development frameworks like WebForms, MVC, JTK Sharp, Silverlight, HTML JS, WPF, and UWP, with a tone that suggests frustration or disbelief. He mentions a cyclical return to Windows Forms and references cross-platform options like "Xamarin Forms, or how it's called."

The clip begins with a male speaker mentioning ".NET Maui" and "Mono's incomplete implementation of WinForms," followed by a dismissive "whatever they're doing." He transitions to a more emphatic tone, stating, "Everybody must download and install the huge .NET runtime," seeing it as "a form of commitment to .NET." Continuing, he mentions that "CIL byte code is easy to reverse engineer" and says they are "basically giving you the code open source for free. How nice of us." He asserts that ".NET Framework is gonna be supported for years to come. It will never die." The speaker notes that "there are still people in remote parts of the world that still haven't heard of .NET Core, .NET 5, Windows Edge, or Firefox." He then observes that C# "is not the only one with cluttered syntax," reminding that "there is still JavaScript." He ends the clip by posing a question: "Why Java developers wear glasses?" followed by a somewhat mocking explanation: "Well if they can't see out of their eyes..."

The audio begins with a male voice suggesting the use of a console to read lines, followed by an instruction to cut the recording. There is a sound of someone getting ready, then an "all right" from the same male voice, followed by "I'm so ready". This is followed by a second male voice saying, "come in, see this" and a few one-to-three-word computer code phrases said by that person, like "byte me," "interrupt," "return to sender," "volatile personality," "unsafe at any speed," and "go to". The same male says a short comment about some code being his, then says "check this" a few times. We hear that packages are being restored for a solution, and this might take a while, followed by a statement about restoring packages and then a need to crunch this. We then hear "Targeting .net 6 and Visual Studio. See, that's what I mean."  Then the statement is made that they don't send crash reports, some analyzer information, and then something about build with 24 errors and a need to take a break. This is followed by someone asking if that's a "CTF again", someone saying they really like the new "nullable operator" and, then saying, "the one of..." something is a "one in a million," followed by a whoop. There is then a question about trying something else, and another whoop. There is mention of using something not supported in C sharp and then sending code in the crash reports.
